												Shadowgrounds is, for me, the quintessential alien shooter. There are no gimmicks, no twists, and barely any surprises. There are aliens, and you shoot them. There may be better alien shooters out there, with more guns or complicated stories or crazier aliens. But Shadowgrounds is the old reliable, the game that you picture in your mind when you think "I want to shoot aliens".In a remote colony on Ganymede you are introduced to Wesley Tyler, a security chief turned mechanic after a tragic backstory had its way with him. The power goes out, and Wesley tags along with two short-lived cohorts to discover that man-eating bugs are crawling out of the reactor. You'll soon find similar chaos breaking out all over the colony, with bigger and angrier aliens to shoot with bigger and angrier guns. Don't expect any complex setpieces or shocking revelations, this is a bug hunt through and through.Shadowgrounds plays from a top-down perspective with a fixed camera above Wesley's head. This allows you to scoot around with WASD while rotating your view with the mouse. It's a simple and effective control scheme that'll have you dancing around ravaging aliens as you fill them full of ordnance. You'll find ten different weapons in your journey, none of them particularly creative but all upgradable using tokens dropped from enemies. These upgrades can be as simple as more damage or faster reloads, or as complex as new fire modes or changes to weapon behavior. It's a nice touch that lets you shore up your weapons in whatever areas you're unsatisfied with, and the fact that you get tokens from enemies will have you always seeking out that next fight.The quest to shoot all the aliens will take you through bases, factories, caves, and starships. Along the way you'll meet more than a few characters that'll give you direction or request your aid. They're all pretty wooden and the voice acting is hammy at best, but there's something endearing about their stiffness, the same way an afternoon movie on SyFy can charm with its ineptitude. This extends to the rest of the game, really. Shadowgrounds has a distinct B-movie feel that's not at all intentional, and is more a produce of its age and budget than anything. And that's not to say there aren't a few sparks of brilliance, like the first time you encounter the stealth aliens.You might have the impression that Shadowgrounds is an unremarkable action game, and you're mostly right. The aliens are a standard mix of bugs and dog-things and serpent men, your guns are the same guns you've been using since Doom, and an infant would be able to predict the plot beats. And yet, there's an earnest charm that keeps me going all the way to the goofy action hero finale. It's well-made for what it is, with clean environments and balanced encounters and plenty of aliens to shoot. It'll last you around four hours total, and there aren't any secrets or achievements to turn up, so it really is just four hours of simply shooting aliens. But we all need to shoot aliens now and then, and sometimes simple is best.

												Shadowgrounds is a fairly classic top down shooter in a style we have all come to know over the years. You run around a number of linear locations stopping every few rooms to fight off a throng of aliens looking to bite your face off. It is all a little too familiar and unfortunately it becomes tiresome rather quickly.The gameplay is very much just that, you run around, shoot aliens, pick up ammo and health and occasionally upgrade your weapons. It's all very generic and something we have seen too many times before.Where Shadowgrounds tries to stand apart from the rest is through the use of atmospheric lighting, or to say it in layman's terms, the game is very dark. At times it's completely pitch black on your screen except for the small cone from your flashlight. It's a fairly well executed feature but being a top down shooter you never really feel those horror elements that the game is trying to provoke.The soundtrack does it's best to add to the scary mood but ultimately cannot overcome the game's basic design problems.In the end, Shadowgrounds is a tired game in a tired genre, although it tries to do something new with the horror elements it never really hits home and you'll find yourself with just another mediocre top down shooter that's all about pumping massive hordes of alien invaders full of lead.

												It's a budget and overtly campy game, allright. But it still gets the job done.Even though the engine behind it shows its age nowadays, Shadowgrounds offers passable visuals with slick lighting and shadow effects, a setting and a threat that's clearly inspired by the 80's sci-fi classic Aliens (which is always a good thing in my book) and most importantly, enjoyable (if mostly repetitive) top-down action that's backed up with responsive controls and relevant mechanics to keep it interesting (i.e., rolling and the weapon upgrades).On the con side, the story is a cliched one and it is presented through uninspired cutscenes with half-hearted voice acting. It only serves as a backbone for introducing challenges and an excuse for killing stuff. Albeit mostly boring, it comes with a nice twist in the end that I enjoyed.Even though not as polished as one might think by looking at the screenshots, Shadowgrounds is a justifiable purchase on a budget price. It's a fine little time-waster that evokes the nostalgia of the classic top-down shooters of the bygone days. Just don't get your hopes that high up and enjoy your relaxed six-hour ride.

												The graphical fidelity and mechanics found in this game might not be the best or most interesting by today's standards, though the lighting is still pretty good, but the atmosphere still holds and is what I found most compelling about this game. I saw a couple instances where the enemies just kinda derped around and didn't attack me, one guy just kinda charged past me and faceplanted into a door, but most of the time they act fairly intelligently and they sometimes even try to flank you--had a couple manage to sneak up on me and take a bite or two. The first boss fight was pretty tough, if fairly repetitive (he has a pattern of attack you need to learn and dance around). They give you up to 4 respawns if you die and the boss' health does not regenerate, but those extra lives are imo more than balanced by the fact that you can't get any more ammo on a respawn (unless you backtrack trying to look for it, I guess). This was also on Medium difficulty, so I would expect Hard to give fewer attempts. The game's supply of med kits and ammo has been fairly reasonable up to this point. It would likely have been more tense and thereby more thrilling on Medium difficulty if I'd had a couple fewer med kits and a bit less ammo, but I'm guessing playing on Hard would fix that. I do plan on finishing the game on Medium and if the rest of the game feels as good as the first hour I'll probably replay it on Hard. Btw at first it seems like you're getting way too much rifle ammo, stacking up over 500 at times, but you really do burn through it quick. And you might want to save as much ammo as possible for the boss fight. Got this game as part of a discounted Frostbite bundle along with Trine and so far both games have been very enjoyable, in different ways. Kudos to Frostbite for making such distinct games that are almost polar opposites yet both styles are very solid (one a tense, atmospheric shooter and the other a relaxing, beautiful platformer).Pricing is a highly subjective matter, I think, especially on older titles like this, but if the price agrees with you and/or you find it on sale and you think you might like an oldschool shooter with a dark atmosphere and an isometric perspective, then yeah I'd highly recommend giving this game a try. 												Shadowgrounds is a fun, retro shooter. It's presented in a top down format, rather than as a FPS. The graphics are not world class, but do the job nicely. Likewise the story is certainly cliche - a space outpost is overrun by murderous aliens with a few survivors left to fight back and get out alive - but it is presented in a nice way and kept me entertained.I would recommend using a game controller with this game. For me that worked great vs. a bit of frustration with keyboard and mouse.I found the game to be slightly challenging without becoming frustrating. Each level gives you four respawns which reset for each new level. If/when you die you respawn a short distance from where you died and the level is exactly as when you died. In other words, any enemies you nerfed are still dead, etc. If you use up all your respawns (I assume) you must restart the level. There is no saving during a level, so you must either complete the current level or if you need to close the program you'll be forced to restart at the beginning. Due to this, my playtime is padded as I left the game running in the background a few times when I needed to step away.There is a decent amount of variety in that there are about a dozen weapons to find and use and various upgrades to buy for each weapon. You won't have enough upgrade points to max out every weapon, so some thought needs to be used in deciding which to buy.The enemies come in about six or seven different types which most of those types having several toughness levels. Throw in a few boss fights over the course of the game and it maintains interest over the half dozen or so hours it takes to run through. If you can pick this up for a buck or two, I would go for it. Nice few days of fun to be had.

Posted: September 10, 2014
												Shadowgrounds is an action over the head shooter from Frozenbyte that got a lot of mixed reviews so I got curious and had to review it myself as well.Indeed the game is a bag that can give you mixed feelings. The intro starts off wich seems to be the setting for your basic military experiment/conspiracy, which even though it has written low budget all over it, it still kind of sets the games premises on pretty good.The menu is looking ok as well and the background always keeps it a bit interesting and makes you hope something is going to happen . The first thing you will notice is that it DOES NOT have a save option.Yes, in this game you cannot save. You just have a couple of lives/respawns after wich it is game over. Like in the good old PlayStation Arcade games. This may put off a lot of people because the game can be surprisingly hard at some points, but for people like me it is a welcoming challenge. For all the others, well at least there is a save progress at the start of each level at least.The story starts off with the hero (Tyler) , a former military , current mechanic guy , beeng sent to fix some random generators with his buddies. The starting tone was very creepy and reminded me of a Dead Space atmosphere, which was great to notice, considering that this game is definetly not a triple A title. You fix the generators and notice that all the sudden there are bodies and blood everywhere,and surprisingly enough there is an alien invasion on your planet. You meet the army and start cleaning up. While not the most original type of story (has Doom 3) written all over it, the story holds up surprisingly well.Moving on to the characters. All of them, including Tyler, seem very under developed. The game tries to tell you something at the start to make you care,but it just fails to deliver or generally fails at the character development section.Graphic wise, everything seems decent, even though most of the graphics seem a bit washed up,even for a top down shooter. The details to the terrain/rooms are quite astonishing at some points. Overall the graphic,while not impressive in any way,does its job, just because of the attention to detail.The character models look just really low budget and plain dumb. The graphics type for the characters is really low quality compared to the overall graphics of the game.Music and sound FX. These just do their job but nothing more. No memorable music here and the SFX just blend in with the atmosphere. Some sound FX reminded me of the first Unreal game for some reason.The enemies, are your generic alien types and all are very annoying because they can just randomly appear in front of you and outnumber you directly. Their attack types get some time to get used to,and you do need some patience with each. You cannot just rush everything because you will die extremely fast.Gameplay and atmosphere. The game tries a dark and gritty atmosphere that initially delivers very well but it is just lost along the way. The flashlight object shadowing mechanic is very cool to look at but it gets old too quick. Overall the atmosphere is fairly decent, the game does tempt you to go back and finish it.Regarding gameplay only. It is quite satisfying to roll over large amounts of aliens but there are several points when it just feels unpolished. You need to do a lot of barrel rolling to avoid instant kill and you need to be aware of your environment all the time because if you hit a wall or an object,the character fails to respond quickly enough,and this causes a delay in movement,delay which will most of the time get you killed. This “stuck syndrome” is met in a large number of times,and really brings the game down as especially in the outdoor environments, you can get stuck a lot in the terrain because there are invisible walls in the middle of the map or the terrain was intended to be unpassable but on the map it looks just normal walking terrain. The gameplay overall feels initially good but gets repetitive and feels too hard at some points.The weapons to me were very disappointing. While the game does have some sort of upgrade system to keep things interesting, I found myself way too many times using the standard pistol with unlimited ammo because everything else has very scarce ammo. Speaking of weapons, most of them seem very ineffective to the aliens. You waste an entire magazine on one enemy at times. Now this beeing good or bad,it is debateble. It does add a survival element to the game, but this element feels like it just happen to be in the game. Does not seem an intended behaivour. The ammo supplies are low, the weapons are largely ineffective and the only thing that keeps this aspect up is the upgrade system,which turns like a chore fast. It’s does not feel crucial on what type of upgrades you need to take.Throughout the game you get upgrade parts to upgarde the weapons, which is a bit refreshing but again,gets old fast and also you find several computer terminals that fill in on the back story.After managing to finish the game, I realized that the atmospheric music was much better than what it was initially and also what seemed to be a generic military/alien invasion had quite an interesting twist in the end. The story seemed stale throught the game but the ending was really weird to witness. Also with the right upgrades,the weapons DO seem to deliver some punch ,but for me it was still a bit of a disappointment.I will recommend this game to fans of the genre and even to people that just want something new. Be advised, that the game is good but it is definetely not great, it does have the weight of a budget title all over it, but in the end it manages to deliver.

												I want to like this game more than I actually do. Overall, it's fun, which is the point, and why I clicked the Recommend button, but there are some flaws that detract from the amount of fun I could be having.First, the graphics. They may seem slightly dated, but that isn't the issue. The biggest problem is the lack of options. My screen is 16:9, but the screen seems to display in something like 2.33:1, so everything is squished. Another problem is the lack of antialiasing, and while this might not be as noticeable if I could set the graphics to my screen's native resolution, the two problems combined really take away from the immersion.Second, the controls. I've tried both keyboard/mouse and a 360 controller, the latter of which seems like the better option for an isometric shooter. The default values are difficult to use at best. Why are the triggers used for rotating the camera instead of firing weapons? And why is the camera so overly touchy? When I switched to the KB/mouse combo, the WASD setup was fine for most things, but camera rotation became such an issue that I simply avoided it.I could make the writing and voice acting the third issue, and for some it may be problematic. I am a lover of B flicks however, so I didn't buy this game expecting a deep, rich story, or Hollywood A-list acting. While the script is predictable and the acting wooden, I could easily look past this and enjoy the game if it wasn't for the other flaws. (I've seen and loved almost every episode of MST3K, and if you know what that means, you'll understand.)The one thing I have yet to check out is the main reason I bought it: co-op. Alas, if I can't sort out the issues with the controls, I don't know if I will bother. What I wanted was a PC version of Dead Nation, the brilliant PSN co-op zombie shooter. What I got was something less polished, and ultimately, less fun.So why recommend it? Overall, it is somewhat fun, so if you get it on sale, go for it. There is some atmostphere about it, and some nice mechanics, including the weapon upgrade system--though this too lacks depth. Kill a critter and get some magic "upgrades"? How does that work exactly? This aside, and if you can look past the other flaws, it might be a nice way to waste some time.Stay tuned for my review of the spin-off/sequel, Shadowgrounds Survivors, where I'm hoping that some of the issues listed above have been fixed. First, I need to finish this game.Graphics: 6/10Audio: 7/10Gameplay: 8/10Replayability: 8/10Overall: 7/10

tl;dr: a solid twin stick shoooter with fun gameplayShadowgrounds is an alien shooter played from bird's eye perspective. It has a solid single player campaign, serviceable art and sound design and you'll likely enjoy blasting away at its aliens. It's one of those games that are nice for breaking up your routine, e.g. if you usually play puzzle games and are looking for a change now and then. It took me about 8 hours to play through the main campaign, so it's not a heavy time investment. Consider purchasing it when it's on sale.controller and screen setupLet's start of with 2 initial hurdles that you may face:This game doesn't support changing to wide screen resolution (e.g. 1920 * 1080) via the options menuXbox controllers aren't supported out of the box either. Controls can be set ingame, but unfortunately not all of them and some controls like the joysticks didn't register at all.To fix both of these, you'll have to manually edit some text files. If you google the respective problem you'll find easy to follow tutorials. It's not too hard and doesn't take long, but the developer should really add an update so that these options are supported out of the box.Disclaimer: I have not played the game with mouse and keyboard but I imagine it works just fine.gameplayNow that the starting problems are dealt with, how does the game play? It's generally fun and the controls are very responsive. All the guns in this game have characteristics that set them aside and make them better in certain situations and worse in others. Enemies also have weaknesses do different weapons, e.g. some bugs get easily toasted by the flamethrower while other are best taken out by bouncing grenades around the corner. You are often stripped for ammunition in this game, so you'll really have to make use of your entire weaponry instead of always using the most powerful gun. It adds immensely to the tension, the survival aspect and the strategy of the game.The radar that shows nearby enemies (but only if they're moving) is also a good device to both add tension and utility to the game. You can also bring up a map for navigation but this really should have been integrated into the radar!aesthetics and designgraphics The graphics aren't too special (not for 2016 anyways) but the art direction is done very well for this kind of game. The graphics are very clear, meaning you'll always know what the combat situation is like and you'll never be overwhelmed by visual clutter on the screen. The not-as-demanding graphics meant that I could rock along with a solid 60+ frames per second (FPS) at any time, making for a very smooth experience.map and mission designThe map design ranges from boring in some places to stellar in entire section. The fourth chapter/map that you'll play is called "New Atlantis" and shows of this stellar design. It really feels like you're exploring a large research that humans would build on a foreign moon. There's also general multiple ways to reach your destination and little side areas to discover. Unfortunately the game doesn't hold up to this standard in all areas, especially the last mission is rather disappointing and quite different from the rest of the game.enemiesA special shoutout goes to the enemy design. Some of the aliens don't have a sense of hearing! I'm confident this was was intentional by the designers as they are a different species biologically – so why should they have all the senses that humans have!? There's even one type of critter that's basically not very dangerous to you, but hard to hit. So in the end it ends up being a threat by potentially depleting your ammo supply!audioThe sound design is good but not spectacular. Again the design is clean, meaning reduced to what really matters. E.g. there's invisible enemies in the game, but they give off a distinct screaming like sound when you're close. I found the music rather bland and during scripted events it would often overshadow audio cues important to the gameplay. The voice acting is o.k. and servicable for the campaign. Your clearly not buying this game for the shooting and not for its audio.story and settingThe story is quite generic (alien infestation of a human space station) but especially during the first half of the game it has a good nuance of realism: the protagonists simply do what ordinary people would do during such an event. You are not cast into the role of a super human soldier in this game but are simply a mechanic that happens to be there and wants to survive. It completely derails towards the end though (think of the movie Independence Day. In the final stages you are  hacking alien technology, invading the mothership, and performing other quite impossible feats. It's also inconceivable how an alien mothership stockpiles a healthy supply of human medikits and ammunition for human weapons. The aliens also conveniently set up teleporters that let you destroy their shield generators.Throughout the game there's many optional pieces of information that you can gather by looking at computer screens, notes left by survivors, etc. These give you details on the backstory of the universe and add to the immersion. I've enjoyed reading them more then the stiff cutscenes or some of the cheesy dialog.annoyancesI did not encounter any major bugs except once (player and enemy models turned invisible), restarting the mission easily fixed that, but my progress was lost. These things could have been better though:Having to manually edit files for screen resolution and controller setup (see above).On widescreen resolutions the text on screen is kind of warped. You won't be reading a lot during this game though, so no biggie.If you die, you respawn at a set point. During some events spawn points are placed directly next to the enemies though. This can result in you instantly dying again after respawning.There should have been a map integrated into the radar for easier navigation.Cringeworthy dialog lines from the stereotypical characters that are meant to come off as cool.resumenAll in all this game focusses on the essentials and gets them right. Buy this game if you're looking for fun gunplay & shooting, don't care about a deep story and enjoy scavenging through abandoned space stations. I also recommend it if you don't usually play twinstick shooters (like me) but want to venture into the genre.

												This review is for the game ''Shadowgrounds''.Developer:FrozenbyteRelease dates:Windows: November 11, 2005 (Finland, Germany)Linux:September 16, 2009,Mac OS X:April 13, 2011,Steam:May 8, 2006Genre:Single player,local co-op top-down shooter(shoot em up)RecapThere's not much to tell since it's a really straightforward game.The plot is really simple-some would say cliché- about Wesley Tyler, a senior mechanic on the IGTO Repair Base on Jupiter's satellite Ganymede,whose responsibility is to repair various systems.During his work he finds some dead bodies,then finds a pistol and other forms of weaponry and -oh the irony- alliens begin to invade the planet(in this case the satellite).You have to progress through 11 levels,save some troopers,destroy some engines and kill many(many many many) hostile aliens.In the end(spoiler alert) you will find out that the aliens really weren't that bad,though they had fallen victims to their own greed and destroyed their own home planet and most of their own race with that kind of technology.That's why they've been monitoring the human race and when they found out they would use that kind of energy.Our hero and his friends decide to give the AMEW bomb back and save eventually the entire solar system(surprising right?)Pros: 1)Simple yet enjoyable story,2)Pleasant time consuming(and yes that's a pro for me),3)Fairly cheapCons:1)Limited, no-brainer skill costumization,2)Not much of a challenge(aliens and alien bosses are really easy even at the hardest difficulty,3)Lame voice acting and some of the lamest quotes in gaming.Overall a nice pleasant time consuming game.I recommend this game but not for the people who need a challenge though.Thank you Frozenbyte Developers for this game :).

I did however encounter a bug on 1 chapter which was literally right at the end of said chapter causing me to have to restart that particular chapter which irritated me somewhat. It was after prepping the space ship and the automated defense robots activate and come after you. I was on around 11hp after some poor combat vs the big ♥♥♥♥ers with forcefields and guns for hands. 												No-one needs this game. It is entirely unessential. It is, however, pretty fun.This is a top-down third person shooter, and, most importantly, the mechanics work pretty well. It's fun to shoot the many different monster types, especially once you upgrade your weapons so you have a range of different strategies you can take. The game is fairly easy (and quite short, about 9 hours), and if one part feels too hard then it's time to work out another strategy, at which point it'll probably become quite easy again. I do like the variety this provides, though, with the stealthy bits being particularly fun but rather short.The graphics in-game are not so awful that it takes you out of the game, and there's a nice use of light and shadow, which improves the atmosphere. The music is absolutely awful, the kind of dross that Eastern European rock kids toss out when they first get access to a synthesiser. You can turn it off but it'll come back on during cut-scenes. The cut-scenes are pretty painful as it is, with terrible voice acting by the bland characters advancing a forgettable, and ultimately, nonsensical story. I do quite like the back-story you pick up by reading computer terminals dotted around the map, although a lot of it is fairly poorly written.I should say that I didn't come across any bugs, apart from one room where the cut-scene at the end showed I should have endured some bullet hell and in fact I got one measly alien I finished off straight away then wandered around aimlessly for a few minutes. Sometimes if you accidentally do things in the wrong order then you might miss part of the story, but I'm pretty sure it won't be too big a loss. The friendly AI is bearable, if a little annoying when they get in your way, but at least they can't die and will attract enemy fire - although you can argue this brings you out of the reality of things a bit.In short, it's worth it if it's on sale for a quid or whatever, but you have to wonder if you want just another game clogging up your steam library. It is, however, a nice little game that is fun whilst it lasts.

												Seemed a bit simple and generic at first, but it became clear that this is all about the gameplay and the frenzied action that goes with it.  I highly recommend this game because it has what matters most: lots of satisfying fun.I didn't think I liked isometric shooters - then I played this one.  The controls took a brief getting-used-to, and once I had, I was roll-flipping-behind-the-back shotgunning aliens in 360 degrees.  So fun.The sequel introduced physics objects - which I think is actually a very bad idea, as they briefly slow down the flow of time in the game on older computers.  Part of what makes this original Shadowgrounds so great is it's silky-smooth and consistent gameplay throughout.  Nothing drives me nuts more than inconsistent flow-of-time / speed-of-time in a game.  (I'm looking at YOU, EA.)  I'd much rather have simple graphics and solid-as-steel gameplay than super HD realism and feeling like some man behind the curtain is filddling with the universe's speed-dial, screwing up my reaction time.Seriously.  Action games are all about reflexes, judging and anticipating movement - hitting stuff that moves with other stuff that moves.  If you were about to hit a baseball as it flies towards your bat at 92.6 miles an hour... and suddenly, 10 feet before it reaches you, just as you are releasing your wind-up... the ball decides to move at 84.5 mile an hour until it passes your already-swung bat, accelerating to an unexplainable 135 miles an hour as it no-clips through the wall.  No.This game does not have that problem, so buy it - and relish in it's mindless alien-slaughtering, earth-saving glory.

Posted: April 5, 2016
												Shadowgrounds from Frozenbyte is a top-down sci-fi alien murderfest.  Shoot thousands of giant bugs and cyborg spiders with a multitude of different weapons.Humanity has successfully terraformed Ganymede, and there is a burgeoning scientific and military presence establishing a foothold here.  But when the power generator is mysteriously sent offline, the mechanic Tyler has to go investigate.  Turns out there is blood smeared everywhere and bodies lying all over.  What he finds after that will change the course of history.  The story tries to take itself seriously, but in all honesty, it isn’t very original or all that engaging.  But it’s a good enough excuse for indiscriminately blowing up aliens.Shadowgrounds is a top-down shooter, which takes a few minutes to get used to, as atmospheric games like this usually are in first person.  The game is focused on exploring the different alien-infested buildings in each level, finding keycards to unlock the next section, and shooting anything that moves.  You’ll constantly be concerned with your ammo reserves (especially on boss levels, as bosses can take A LOT of damage) but for most of the game ammo is plentiful.  Enemies have an annoying tendency to be bullet sponges, requiring you to empty a clip or more into some of them in order to kill them.  You’ll never be completely helpless, as your pistol has infinite shots.  The other weapons are all unique and satisfying to use, each giving you different strategies to employ and allowing you an easier time of taking out certain enemies.  Dead aliens will sometimes drop upgrade parts, which you can spend to give your weapons new abilities like higher damage, rapid fire, or extended magazines.  You can read documents that have been left lying around on PDAs or on computers in order to figure out what is really going on, but it is completely optional, and frankly not all that interesting.The visuals are pretty simplistic, and the textures of the different buildings do little to set themselves apart from one another.  But the way the game handles lighting is superb.  The smaller alien bugs will actually run away from you if your flashlight is on.  This is useful knowledge, but know that objects like crates or doors will block your flashlight just like in real life.  The way light bends (or more accurately, doesn’t) around corners is a surprisingly nice touch.  In later levels, you’ll come across invisible enemies that will flicker in the beam of your flashlight, giving an eerie screech as they try to dismember you.The audio quality is passable, overall.  The voice acting is definitely the low point, as lines are delivered with over-the-top and unconvincing cheesiness.  The soundtrack is this cool hard rock techno you might find in a summer action movie, which fits the theme very well.  Enemy screeches and clanging objects will let you know what is coming once you learn how each enemy behaves.The biggest issue with this game is that it really wants me to care about the story it is trying to tell, and while I enjoyed it near the end, it was quite diffult to get into.  The subpar voice acting doesn’t really help in that regard, but I enjoyed my time in Shadowgrounds.  The developers did a great job making levels seem just a little different from each other, which gives some uniqueness to each encounter.  In one, you’ll be defending a base full of survivors from waves of attackers, and in another you’ll be negotiating a twisting canyon as aliens climb down and surprise you.Having said all that, do I recommend Shadowgrounds?  The easiest way I can describe it is that it feels like a poor man’s Halo.  Fun, frentic combat makes up for a lot of the game’s other faults, and playing it on Easy is a decent waste of a Saturday afternoon, but I wouldn’t say you’ll be missing out on much if you skip this game.

												+ Solid action. Rather simple, but it's working. Needs no hour-long tutorials. Drop in, shoot stuff. Very few keys, easy to control. A game reduced to proven core features. You know what you get. A nice and fun no-brainer in times where other games sometimes tend to be overly ambitious or blown up with features no one ever needed or asked for.+ Nicely varied levels with thoughtful assets+ A pretty nice ambiance+ Some nice music tunes~ Story isn't the most original one, but solid enough~ Graphics and physics aren't fantastic, but solid enough (nice lighting though, your flashlight is generating nice light breaks and shadows and all)~ Many guns offering versatility. But in the heat of battle I found it difficult to find the weapon best suited for the situation. You have 8 or so towards the end. You press number buttons or use the mouse wheel to switch around. But you cannot reassign the guns from what I've seen, so you may switch around more during battle than you would want to. But the game, while having a few tense moments even on "Easy" difficulty, overall isn't too difficult, so no big harm I guess.- Characters are either somewhat bland or cheesy- Voice acting probably could have been better, at least for some characters. I've heard far worse though.- A few sloppy level design parts I noticed, where I could walk into rock formations in the surrounding area I shouldn't have been able to walk into. My character clipped through them, I could only see his head through the pile of sand and stone. Most players will never stray that far off from the main route, I guess, but if you give people the possibilty to roam around I suppose you should test these areas to not have such flaws, especially since this isn't something on the scale of an Elder Scrolls or Armed Assault game. Luckily I never got stuck there or anything.- Mission design has a few logic flaws too. In some levels you can access some areas before being told so mission-wise. This may trigger events, like new enemy types getting stalking-like appearances on you, which should have been spared for when you were really meant to go there. One level I was able to finish without even doing all the objectives I was told to do. Going into detail may spoil it, perhaps the devs intended to give some freedom there as that specific level was still logically working without all the objectives done, but I tend more to believe that this was unintended and therefore a bit of a sloppy design too.

												Ah, Shadowgrounds. It's not the best top-down shooter I've ever played.It's unbalanced, gives you at least twice as many guns as you actually need, it's a bit buggy and unpolished. It starts you off really slowly on the first few levels. The shotgun doesn't feel powerful at all even with burst fire, and the Electric Gun came far too late and ended up being pointless. The main character suffers from "gotta roll to go faster" syndrome. The boss in the Mines level is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ as he's faster than you and you have no way to dodge him until he starts rolling and summoning enemies (fun fact, I lost a life). The final boss is disappointing and the ending is just awful. Co-op is local only. But perhaps worst of all, it's too damn short, clocking at a mere 6 hours, and with no reason whatsoever to replay it.And yet, it's definitely one of the most enjoyable. The levels are built in a non-linear fashion and encourage exploration, and despite being somewhat repetitive at times, always come out with many varied challenges. Enemies manage to be varied, even requiring a different approach depending on your arsenal. Most weapons feel fantastic, especially when fully upgraded. The pistol, considering it's your backup infinite-ammo weapon, is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ amazing with the upgrades (though the secondary feels more like a passive skill, which was indeed the result in the sequel). Some of the effects and scenery are jaw-dropping, even today (♥♥♥♥ yeah particles). The soundtrack, especially in action sequences, really makes you pump adrenaline with all its awesomeness. It's jolly good fun.Oh, and it's also absurdly cheap on sale, a mere 99 cents for the two games. So what the heck are you waiting for?

												Ah, Shadowgrounds. It's not the best top-down shooter I've ever played.It's unbalanced, gives you at least twice as many guns as you actually need, it's a bit buggy and unpolished. It starts you off really slowly on the first few levels. The shotgun doesn't feel powerful at all even with burst fire, and the Electric Gun came far too late and ended up being pointless. The boss in the Mines level is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ as he's faster than you and you have no way to dodge him until he starts rolling and summoning enemies (fun fact, I lost a life). The final boss is disappointing and the ending is just awful. Co-op is local only. But perhaps worst of all, it's too damn short, clocking at a mere 6 hours, and with no reason whatsoever to replay it.And yet, it's definitely one of the most enjoyable. The levels are built in a non-linear fashion and encourage exploration, and despite being somewhat repetitive at times, always come out with many varied challenges. Enemies manage to be varied, even requiring a different approach depending on your arsenal. Most weapons feel fantastic, especially when fully upgraded. The pistol, considering it's your backup infinite-ammo weapon, is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ amazing with the upgrades (though the secondary feels more like a passive skill, which was indeed the result in the sequel). Some of the effects and scenery are jaw-dropping, even today (♥♥♥♥ yeah particles). The soundtrack, especially in action sequences, really makes you pump adrenaline with all its awesomeness. It's jolly good fun.Oh, and it's also absurdly cheap on sale, a mere 99 cents for the two games. So what the heck are you waiting for?

												Shadowgrounds - it's good, very good.In a nutshell it's a total rip-off every single sci-fi horror movie with aliens in it, especially Aliens. You get to play a mechanic blasting your way through 11 levels of mayhem with a good variety of weapons with upgrades that will change how you use each weapon in different scenarios and also helps to cater for different styles of play.It's a top down shooter where you are investigating the strange going ons at the space station where you work. The game itself has been heavily influenced by the Aliens franchise and this is apparent in the unfolding storyline which wont win any awards and is very linear but serves it purpose for providing a good narrative to give you reason to pump alien♥♥♥♥♥full of lead. I myself totally loved the storyline - it's almost like an Aliens fanboy spinoff movie. As well as this there are very clear influences from seminal games of the past like Quake2 and there are quite a few other little influences in the game from movies and games of this genre but i will leave for you to spot them and not spoil it all for you.The graphics themselves are nothing to write home about but the awesome lighting and shadow effects and very good sound effects combined with a minor level of strategy in the use of your rechargable flashlight give the game a really good edge. At times you will find yourself low on health prowling around with your flashlight looking for a medikit. The game recreates the feeling of arcade machines of old by giving you NO save points on levels. You start a level and finish it or next time start from the start. You have 5 retries/lives and this helps to create that arcade feeling by not letting you have unlimited retries. This however in itself i feel is the only real big letdown of the game. Although for some gamers this will make no difference it will make a big difference to the more casual gamer who isn't able to spend a long time scouring the levels looking for the extra weapons and ammo stashes that all games like this have. This means that as you progress further into the game you have to have more time to complete a level because if you dont finish that level in that sitting the next time round you have to start from the start of that level again. No checkpoints - no saves - only 5 retries per game. Despite this one annoying detail it is a really good game especially if you can get hold of the Shadowgrounds Pack (on sale at time of writing) for less that £2.00.This is a good game and the keyboard mouse controls work really really well on this game. A lot of games like this fail badly because of poor control system but the devs for this game have got this spot on for this game. This is also one of the reasons i can recomend this game. The controls feel very natural and you wont find yourself madly bashing buttons at anytime because the controls work well and feel intuitive after 5 minutes of playing the game. The different skill levels will provide a good challenge for more experienced players and the option of local coop make this game even more of a reason to buy it.Oh you actually read this far?Why?Just go buy the game - you will spend £2 on worse things in your life. Enjoy.
